info.name: Cube Conveyor
info.attribution:
Layout, design, and library image by LawDawg96. Released to the Public Domain under CC0.

Wood grain background by RyanPro available under the Pixabay license from https://pixabay.com/photos/trees-wood-yellow-wood-oak-1915247/

Tile bag by mousewax available as CC0.
info.description: Control production areas on the board to earn points when cubes move through.
info.ruleText:
Players sit in seats. Click the Restart button to set up the game and randomly select a player to begin.

Objective:

Earn victory points (VP) when cubes move from groups that are controlled by your player or when you move cubes from uncontrolled groups. The player with the most VPs at the end of the game wins.

Turns:

Turns consist of two steps.
  • Place a tile
During your turn, start by placing a tile from your hand on the board so that it touches any existing tile. Tiles do not have to match color. A tile can connect 2 groups unless both groups have workers on them (even if the workers are from the same player). Tiles may be played inside the starting ring and you may leave gaps in the board.

Click a tile to rotate it.

If you do not have a tile in your hand at the start of your turn, draw a tile and your turn ends immediately.
  • Spend action points (AP)
You have up to 3 AP to spend per turn. You do not have to spend them all, but unused APs do not carry over to the next turn.  Choose from any of the following options in any order:

1. Place a worker (2 APs). Take a worker from your supply and move it to any unoccupied group of one or more connected hexes of the same color. Fill all of the circles on that group with cubes.

2. Production (1 AP). Move cubes on the board. Cubes must move through the board in sequential order, from tiles numbered 1 to 6. The groups do not have to be adjacent, you do not have to control either group, and the group can even be uncontrolled by any player. You can move as many cubes as there are unoccupied circles on the destination group.

To move to tiles numbered 1, drag cubes from the cube bag or double-click the tile to automatically place a cube there. Put one cube for each circle in the group of 1 tiles.

To move cubes from a group 1-5 to the next higher group, drag and drop the cubes according to the requirements in this section. It costs 1 AP per destination group, so if you split the move from a single group to multiple destination groups, use 1 AP for each.

To move cubes from a group of 6 tiles, drag and drop them back into the cube bag.

When a cube moves from a group controlled by a player, that player earns 1VP per cube moved. When a cube moves from a group not controlled by any player, the player that did the production earns 1 VP per cube moved.

Use the + button to add VPs to your score (or the - button if you make a mistake). Although exact VP scores are not public information, a colored token moves across the screen when adding or subtracting points so that other players can see that a score has been updated.

3. Draw a tile (1 AP). Draw a new tile from the face up bank of tiles or click the Take One button to get a random tile from the bag. If you take from the bank, use the Fill button to bring the bank back up to 4 tiles.

You cannot have more than 5 tiles in your hand at any time. You must end your turn with at least 1 tile or face the penalty of not being able to use APs on your next turn after drawing a single card.

4. Move a worker (1 AP). Move 1 of your workers on the board to any other unoccupied group. Leave any cubes that were on the vacated group where they were and do not fill the new group with cubes from the bag.

After a player's turn ends, click the Turn button to move the turn clockwise (top to bottom in the room) and the next player starts their turn.

End of Game

The game ends immediately when it is no longer possible to refill the bank of tiles to 4. Use the Show Score button to reveal all players' VP scores. The player with the most VPs wins.
info.helpText: Use mouse wheel, pinch on mobile, or blue and white VTT menu buttons to zoom in and out on the screen. The pieces are intentionally small so that they can all fit without adjusting the position of the board. Once zoomed in, click and drag anywhere on the empty board to pan the view. Each player independently controls their own zoom and pan.
